title: Will China's National People's Congress or its Standing Committee pass a property tax law before 1 October 2019?
preds:
It should happen, but not that fast I believe. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/china-parliament-property/update-1-chinas-property-tax-will-be-implemented-according-to-the-city-lawmaker-idUSL3N21129L
It seems that China is preparing the tax but for October time seems to be running out.

It looks like China will implement a new property tax law, but the question is more one of timing.  It is likely that, as one of the objectives is to reduce the amount of property speculation, the law will be implemented with little warning - possibly outside of one of the regular parliamentary meetings.

This law has yet to be submitted to the NPC's Standing Committe for deliberation. Probably its draft is not ready yet. In any case the next regular meeting of the NPC's Standing Committe is expected for late october (there is a special session this month, but not with the purpose of passing legislation). Thus it's probably impossible that it will be passed.
Only 1 month left and for a draft law to become legislation that is unheard of.
Little chance before 1 October 2019 but increasingly likely thereafter

China has consolidated property ownership data, but to levy tax is a separate struggle On the contrary, the potential implementation of the tax is already facing headwinds, according Yao and other analysts. The government’s 10-year debate on the implementation and the shift from a 2019 deadline to complete necessary legislative procedures to an indefinite one are indications of its hesitation. Analysts are diverged on how soon the legislation will come into place, but most expected an extended phase-in period, with the first or second homes to be exempted from taxation to minimise initial impact.
https://www.scmp.com/property/hong-kong-china/article/2152388/china-has-consolidated-property-ownership-data-levy-tax

Beijing’s plan to unveil a nationwide property tax could become a casualty of the escalating US-China trade war, as efforts to push ahead with draft legislation on the new levy appear to be temporarily on hold. Rising uncertainty in the international environment means that “conditions are not ready” for rolling out a property tax law, Zhang Yiqun, an official with China Law Society, a policy institute under China’s Ministry of Finance, told the Securities Daily in a report on Wednesday.
https://www.scmp.com/property/hong-kong-china/article/3010328/chinas-plan-tax-property-takes-unexpected-twist-thanks
End date drawing nearer. Hard to imagine that the PC will want to impose something unpopular and potentially disruptive to the economy at this moment in time. Leaving 5% b/c politics is politics...
Not enough time to act to meet the question date, hat tip to @Raisinville
Legislation being drafted related to curbing land speculation. Increased odds to 5%.

Draft of the tax plan may be available by year end. From: https://www.reuters.com/article/china-parliament-property/update-1-chinas-property-tax-will-be-implemented-according-to-the-city-lawmaker-idUSL3N21129L:
"Work on a draft property tax in China is “steadily advancing”, senior Chinese parliamentary officials said last week during the country’s annual parliament meeting.
"The comment sparked speculation that Beijing may be looking at submitting a draft tax proposal for review this year, triggering a drop in the share prices of Chinese property developers."

- Next session is in August - no session before October 1 after that
- No property tax draft law proposal available for public comment
- Reports of work done on a draft, but this is a major law, years in the making will not be rushed through without notice.
They need to do this sooner or later, but later looks much more likely in the current circumstances.
Takes time to tinker with taxes.
Reducing, China messaging out lower tax rates.

- house census is outdated
- NPC meeting takes place annually in March
Revising down with passage of time making it less likely and noting that the crowd probably knows more about this than do I.

Most governments are looking for revenue streams. Property tax is a new source of revenue for infrastructure improvement needed in China. https://www.reuters.com/article/china-parliament-property/update-1-chinas-property-tax-will-be-implemented-according-to-the-city-lawmaker-idUSL3N21129L

-Raising on "work on a draft property tax in China is “steadily advancing” comment from Chinese official -- they probably tell it like they are ordered to tell it. 
-l learned (at cost to brier) that China telegraphs its political intent domestically using calculated media announcements and/or high-ranking official presence
- and "legislation will be submitted for review as soon" as has been generally alluded to in media reports...maybe by July
- at least a decade to research this tax, and it's implementation and impact... so assuming the details are already known and ready to go.
- Politbureau determines the parameters of the tax amount, but gives the municpalites some leeway to pick aspects of it.
- municipalities using sale of land to increase revenues seems counter-productive to increase municipal wealth so disounting that as a reason. Taxation is a steadier, more controllable source of revenue that doesn't require giving away assets.
- Housing is a bit of a lottery anyway, so maybe intent is to even playing field (or concentrate players?)
- China needs the money, especailly if Hong Kong rebels. https://news.cgtn.com/news/3d3d774e3355444e33457a6333566d54/index.html
http://www.ipti.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/IPTI-Xtracts-China-March-2019-3.pdf crowd around 18%; question is before Oct or after?
Seems unlikely with trade war tensions looming.

Changing my mind. They have a system in place to track real estate transactions but their underlying housing census data is almost 35 years old. Need to update that before you can introduce comprehensive real estate tax law on this scale. "According to the information released by the local statistics department, in 2020, China will conduct the seventh census to thoroughly investigate the changes in the birth of the population and the housing situation. This census will provide a basis for the next step of population policy adjustment and the introduction of real estate tax....Prior to this, Zhou Wei, a member of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference and the director of the Housing and Urban-Rural Development Department of Jiangsu Province, also suggested that in the 35 years after the first national urban housing survey in 1985, China's urban population, families and their housing conditions have already occurred. Earth-shaking changes. Combined with the seventh national census work to be carried out in 2020, the second national urban housing survey will be carried out simultaneously, which will lay a solid data foundation for the improvement of the housing system in China." [1]http://finance.china.com.cn/house/20190516/4980302.shtml

They’ve talked about this for extended period of time and doesn’t seem any closer. As growth slows, doubt they would implement a tax that could exasperate things...  having said all that, info to support is opaque (for me at least)
They will try and if they don’t succeed they will continue in 2020 to attempt it and likely succeed by February 2020, if not sooner.
The stress on the geopolitical map will currently stall or stop any form of taxes on property also the immanent global economic slowdown and/or recession.
The government has shifted pretty decisively in the opposite direction, embracing stimulus in response to the trade war rather than imposing new taxes.
Revising down in light of lack of clear signal out of standing committee. Do not think they will surprise market, particularly with the trade dispute getting heated.

"During the two sessions this year, real estate taxes were frequently mentioned. On March 27th, the Boao Forum for Asia, the real estate tax issue once again attracted attention. All economists involved in the survey believe that although the real estate tax is expected to accelerate, this year may still be the year of preparation before landing." Translated through Google Translate. survey of Chinese economists:
https://www.yicai.com/news/100182441.html

Although the Standing Committee published 11 tax bills that include property tax measures and seem to desire to push them through (http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1118788.shtml), the housing market in China is very bubbly and with an increased economic pressure from President Trump's tariffs, they cannot afford the risk at the moment. The legislation itself is also under review as there are multiple steps still to have been taken before it could be enacted (https://www.scmp.com/business/money/wealth/article/2135755/fleeting-relief-chinas-homeowners-property-tax-inches-its-way). There is a chance that they still push the legislation through, but I doubt it will occur before October 1st of this year, as the current pressure is too great.
I expect they will be cautious to avoid crashing the housing market but will look to restrain the excess.
What legislative body wants to ignore a potentially massive source of revenue, especially when they can just do it.
China’s communist leaders want to be seen as decisive.
China needs money, and since they're an expansionist society, this is practically a guarantee of income for them.
The communist Chinese like laws they cannot or will not enforce.
the housing market is too big a driver for the economy.  if any implementation it will be a small / token signal implementation
Seems a big task so soon
There is no support for such a measure that could grow large enough for this to happen by October 1st, 2019

I believe that if China passes a law relating to real estate/property, it would be designed as an incentive for Chinese investors to divest from foreign markets (especially in the US, where Chinese investors hold significant sway over bubbly housing on the US west coast, for example in Seattle) and bring those funds back to the Chinese homeland to prop up property values within China. Avoiding an economic collapse is critical for China, especially during a trade war with a country it may be able to successfully negotiate against if it does not face a crisis.
Adjusting downward from my earlier estimate to account for narrower window of time than "all of 2019".

This seems like a really hard call. Apparently, this has been suggested for "more than a decade" [1]. More concretely, the "legislation for property taxes has been listed on National People’s Congress work agenda since 2015" [2]. It's not clear to me what the base rate for something like this ought to be. It seems to be a "Class 1 Project", but again I don't have any numbers for this. Rule of three doesn't work here since small sample size and one-off event.  It seems to be hard to argue for a base rate higher than 20% given this evidence. Concrete evidence regarding this year:
- In March, Chinese markets seem to have reacted to announcements surrounding such a law. Stock prices of major Chinese property developers sank by more than 10%. [1] Apparently, this has happened before though. [3] "[S]hares have largely recovered since." [6]
- Apparently, even after drafting such a law (which they claim to want to do this year), passing such a law takes significant amounts of time: "the process of drafting a law must go through several readings in the Chinese legislature, before it goes for public feedback." [2] No concrete draft has yet surfaced.
- I also found this "The best guess is that legislation will be in place by 2023 when the current legislature ends its term, before the enactment of the levy follows, according to a report by Citic Securities." [2] Similar sentiment expressed here [4]. Assuming uniform probability over that time, we get between 10% to 15% for the time before October 1. I'd assume it's skewed toward the end though.
- This guy with a vested interest says it won't happen now. [5] I have a hard time seeing that this will happen with more than 12% probability. [1] https://www.caixinglobal.com/2019-03-09/china-makes-property-tax-a-legislative-priority-101389716.html
[2] https://www.scmp.com/property/hong-kong-china/article/2189497/china-sounds-clarion-call-property-tax-causing-real-estate
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/china-parliament-property/update-1-chinas-property-tax-will-be-implemented-according-to-the-city-lawmaker-idUSL3N21129L
[4] https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/real-estate/china-will-allow-cities-to-set-their-own-property-taxes
[5] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/03/23/property-taxes-would-have-a-huge-impact-on-chinas-economy-ceo.html
[6] https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-03-14/china-s-developers-don-t-need-to-worry-about-a-property-tax-yet
Legislative process for such a law will certainly take longer than 6 months and it's now already April.

It would have huge consequences and could instantly bring down the economy. Jim Chanos mentioned how shocked he was when he learned how much building has been going on in China, with tons of empty office space now the results...
Eventually the problem has to be addressed and property taxes would mean a lot more money for communities... tough call.

Decreasing probability because:
1) National People's Congress is over and no action taken on property taxes.
2) South China Morning Post, a mouthpiece of the government, predicts legislation doesn't hit until 2023 ( https://www.scmp.com/property/hong-kong-china/article/2189497/china-sounds-clarion-call-property-tax-causing-real-estate ) Leaving a 2% probability that some sort of tax framework is still passed by the standing committee this year.
China needs capital to fund the country's scientific and trade agendas.

Tough call and acknowledging @cafebedouin contrarian view
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-07/china-gets-closer-to-game-changing-property-tax-as-bill-drafted
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/03/23/property-taxes-would-have-a-huge-impact-on-chinas-economy-ceo.html

During the national legislative sessions, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said that China will steadily push forward property tax legislation [1].  According to law professor Liu Jianwen at Peking University, who is the head of the Fiscal and Tax Law Research Institute at the China Law Society, a draft law for property tax will be submitted for review this year.  However, it is a "relatively long process" between the property tax plan and the NPC Standing Committee's review to its final implementation, Liu said, adding, "it will depend on the maturity of the property tax law draft and the majority consensus of the measure to be formed in society." While China will eventually pass a property tax law, it is very unlikely that it will happen by 1 October 2019. [1] http://www.ecns.cn/news/economy/2019-01-22/detail-ifzcuekn4079067.shtml
Thank you, @D_L_Parks! Anyone who doesn't want to gets slaughtered by this question should consider what he posted at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/834956

Recent articles concerning this question really feel like the "it's just a matter of time" predictions that Tetlock abhors. Bloomberg says, "With Beijing keen to get this done, it’s looking like legislation could get passed by 2023."[1] Since 2023 is well beyond the closing date of this question, sticking with a "No" resolution for the question. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-03-14/china-s-developers-don-t-need-to-worry-about-a-property-tax-yet

Work on a draft property tax in China is “steadily advancing”, senior Chinese parliamentary officials said last week during the country’s annual parliament meeting. The comment sparked speculation that Beijing may be looking at submitting a draft tax proposal for review this year, triggering a drop in the share prices of Chinese property developers. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-parliament-property/chinas-property-tax-will-be-city-based-with-minimum-tax-free-threshold-senior-lawmaker-idUSKCN1QV0V1?il=0
Keeping it low given Chinese economy. With stock market up 25% (with 6-ish per cent growth in economy) could be further weakness to come.
Dropping a few points given the weakness and uncertainty in China's economy. Their leaders generally switch to stimulus at times like this instead of increasing taxes.

"'When the conditions are ripe, it will be submitted to the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress for initial review,' Uzhitu said, though did not give a timeframe.
The idea of a tax has met with push-back from stakeholders, including local governments that rely heavily on land sales as a key source of financing." https://www.reuters.com/article/china-parliament-property/china-says-drafting-of-property-tax-law-steadily-advancing-idUSL3N20W00K

recent report indicates the tax will not happen for 2-3 years ...could this be accurate?
https://www.asiatimes.com/2019/03/article/china-may-step-up-introduction-of-property-tax/

So, I was using Google a bit on the phrase: 房地产税. The first three are "real estate" and the last character is tax. It seems to be the relevant keyword. Most of the articles were congruent with this article, copying from Google Translate[1]: "At the legislative level, the Standing Committee of the 13th National People's Congress in September 2018 included the real estate tax law in the first category of legislative planning, that is, the conditions are relatively mature, and it is proposed to be reviewed during the term of the Standing Committee of the 13th National People's Congress...[last time this happened was in 2014 when they had a major problem] ...Zhang Dawei, chief analyst of Zhongyuan Real Estate, said that there are many thresholds for real estate tax levy. The most important thing is the legislative process. The second is the basic real estate information registration and the dynamic evaluation system of house prices. Among them, the dynamic evaluation system of house prices is still a major technical problem of real estate tax landing [taxation?]... Recently, Minsheng Securities released a report saying that the central government’s expression of “full authorization” and “street policy” for real estate tax means that the central government’s legislation on real estate tax is more to solve the legal problem of this tax, and on the specific expropriation rules. The local government will be given sufficient authority to select specific levy time, applicable tax rate, and object of collection. The report believes that in the future, the scope of real estate tax collection will be promoted from the first-line and hot-spot second-tier cities to gradually expand the pilot, and the third- and fourth-tier cities will set a higher exempted area, with less or no receipt, the same city. A pattern of gradual expansion from the main urban area to the suburbs." My reading of this is that the property tax law is not about implementation. It is about setting the legal framework for starting the process of implementing a real estate tax. They'll roll it out in a few major cities first where speculation is particularly a problem, try to tighten down the technical problem of determining housing prices, and they will iron out the details and gradually roll this out everywhere. i think the current economic environment is largely irrelevant, since this will clearly be a multi-year process. I'm still inclined to think that they'll pass some kind of legal framework for levying real estate taxes this year, but I'm going to come down a bit, say 70%.  [1] https://wallstreetcn.com/articles/3486523
Holding for now, waiting to see what comes out of the NPC Standing Committee this week.[1] [1] http://www.npc.gov.cn/englishnpc/news/Events/2019-02/28/content_2073601.htm
Don’t know why they haven’t already done this
Reducing from 15%. It looks more likely to be 2020. Crowd: 12% Crowd forecast has tumbled in the last few weeks. http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1136583.shtml
Dropping a few points as I can't find recent news about this story.

In discussion about the percentage of investment in Arkansas by China someone caught my attention with the thought - What if a Property Tax does happen. How disruptive will it be to "UN" cook the books. The same effect would occur with a credible threat to carry through as well. THis could be a useful tool for Xi in controlling the Princes.
Property tax would send a very bearish signal to further cool down the market, which might trigger a chaos in the high debt leveraged economy.
Taxation is a way to control People and business
This seems even more unlikely given that the government is pushing people to purchase excess capacity housing

Dropping a bit because the underlying need for China to have a property tax hasn't changed but given the unpopularity of the move plus the general economic problems the country is facing right now, I think nothing changing is the most likely outcome.

Coming down by 7% to stay ahead of the average. * * This year I'm trying to blend a strategy of "being right" with a combination of The Price is Right One Bid approach for questions when I'm not as certain of the outcome (i.e. - after the next to last contestant makes their bid, the last contestant bids $1 more than the highest bid, basically screwing everybody else unless they go over). It will be interesting to see how this pans out at the end of the year in terms of affecting the overall average and my Brier score in terms of being more right - or potentially more wrong - than average.
Why tax the people when you have vast forex reserves?

They seem to have become nervous about popping the housing bubble in a weakening economy.  (Full disclosure:  The Chinese government does not confide in me, so this is conjecture is sufficiently weak to qualify as a guess.)

@D_L_Parks and @cafebedouin offer good insights and analysis. China needs a property tax, all agree. Taxes are unpopular, especially during economic downturns.
Assuming the trade negotiations with the US continue to drag (trade is not a simple issue), resolution and recovery to the Chinese economy could take quarters. Therefore the best laid plans could be deferred until the time is right, unlikely by the time of this question.

Troubled by this one. Per comments @cafebedouin (all good) but global headwinds. Pushing up a little as further moderation required in China property market and this is one way to get partly there without punishing less wealthy.
Massive stimulus this year already gives CCP the economic re(cover)y needed. Regulatory incentive to moderate next bubble comes later (2020+).

Taking a lowball punt this at this early stage. China has been trying to do this for years but implementing a property tax is extremely tricky because of the risks to the property market, and the longer they leave it the more delicate the problem becomes. Some parts of the Chinese real estate market are exhibiting classic property bubble behaviour. I think legislators know this and are scared of popping the bubble. If the Chinese housing market heats up legislators will be more nervous of acting, if it cools to more moderate growth rates then the urgency is taken out of the situation, but if it crashes then the main driver for a property tax is removed. The more people buy property as an investment not as a dwelling, the greater the need for legislation, but the harder it becomes to pass that legislation because more people stand to lose money as a result. Why 50 Million Chinese Homes are Empty;
https://youtu.be/f5SE47Xjx2Q
I am going off of the evidence I collected shown here: https://www.getguesstimate.com/models/12503, and the biasing myself towards the wisdom of the crowds.

The first quote is what made me decide to start at 95%. I think I'm going to come down to 90% until the 13th NPC Standing Committee convenes on March 3, 2019. At that time, we should have more information to make a more accurate prediction. "China is moving closer to a nationwide property tax. Expected to be rubber-stamped in 2019, the levy will tame speculative market behavior and modernize the system. While legislation was long-delayed until now, actual implementation could span several more years, especially now that the economy is cooling down."[1] "China's long-delayed plan to collect property tax, one of the country's biggest efforts to curb a swelling real estate market, could make headway this year, according to a top tax law expert in China."[2] “If this time around stands out from previous property tax discussions, it’s because the government has put in place the necessary infrastructure,” James Macdonald, Head of China Research at Savills, told CER. “One of the key obstacles that the government had was that they simply didn’t know who owned what – the centralised database lets them clear this hurdle.” On the flipside, however, a recent wave of domestic economic headaches could force officials to push back any legislation with the goal of tempering demand."[3] [1] https://thediplomat.com/2018/08/edward-cheung-on-chinas-modern-property-tax-system/
[2] http://www.ecns.cn/news/economy/2019-01-22/detail-ifzcuekn4079067.shtml
[3] https://chinaeconomicreview.com/is-the-timing-right-for-a-chinese-property-tax/

Given some time to research this question, I think I should have started with a base answer of "No" and then move toward "Yes" if/when the data permit. 1) Past precedent shows that property tax legislation has been shelved every time the economy downturns.
2) Despite rumors, the legislation is not mentioned in the last NPC summary. - http://www.npc.gov.cn/englishnpc/news/Events/2019-01/02/content_2070228.htm
3) The most recent articles on the topic note that the NPC may table a draft version of the law this year, suggesting that the law may not be ready for passage by GJ's deadline.
Curious of my ability to grasp a complex set of variables (often also unknowns), aggregate info and draw conclusions.

Property tax legislation could be submitted for review by China's top lawmaking body, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPC), said Liu Jianwen, a law professor at Peking University and head of the Fiscal and Tax Law Research Institute at the China Law Society, during a forum in Beijing on Monday.
With maturation of economy, property taxes are a good way to tax people with some $ and not upset others. Not sure of timing, however. Lowering until I understand this better.

How long does it take to pass a law in China? As far I have researched, there are 7 steps, and Property Tax is something new in the chinesse fiscal arena, many goverment officials have invested in property, therefor I expect that it will be a hot issue that will take some time to consolidate it into a plausible bill; let alone with the tax refoms inplemented this year regarding to individual income tax and new features as "global income" Chinese Tax Authorities have plenty of work to implement this new reform.  Even more there is the question of implementation. last year China has finished their national property database, and many may think that for that reason a property tax is imminent, and it might; however to actually set a procedure (incluiding reglamentary laws) of how and when the property tax will be paid or collected will take some time, not feasable to accomplish by October this year Finally there is the economic landscape, not looking good for china, US-China Trade War, Chinese economic slowdown, and once again the Income Tax Reform this year, that will make quite difficult for the property tax to take effect this year

Chinese people strongly believe property is the safest and most profitable place to store their money.  In addition to catering the need of housing for the huge Chinese population, the real estate market has a large speculation component.  The rapid rise in real estate price (e.g., 25% per year in Shanghai in 2016) in the last few years created a bubble situation.   While the housing sector is one of China’s main pillars of growth, the market frenzy led to talk of using property tax to curb speculation in 2016.  The immediate implementation of the tax was not possible because creating and implementing a modern property tax system from the scratch is not straightforward [https://thediplomat.com/2018/08/edward-cheung-on-chinas-modern-property-tax-system/].  Furthermore, the infrastructure needed, such as a national database of land-ownership, was not there.   By 2017, the database has been created.  By midyear 2018, there were many news reports suggesting the imminent implementation of a property tax in China.  However, this is eclipsed by the sudden start of the trade war between China and the U.S.  Due to the trade war and the associated uncertainties, the housing market has cooled down.  It is accompanied by a slowdown of the economy.   I believe that, in the long term, the housing sector (and the speculation aspect of it) will come back, I don’t think that the Chinese government wants to introduce this tax in the time of uncertainty now.  Even if the trade war with the US could be resolved in the near future (in a few months if you are optimistic), it would still need time for the economy to re-adjust itself before it is prudent to introduce a brand new tax.  Therefore I forecast a 5% chance that this property tax will be implemented by 1 October 2019.

This time seems to be different with a new database and pilot programs already in place. I'm leaning yes with a delayed and/or piecemeal implementation to address economic concerns. The China Real Estate Association said in a post on its website that legislation may take over five years to push through given current circumstances, citing a former director of state-backed Chinese Academy of Fiscal Sciences. There is also precedent for postponement. Preparations were under way as part of a five-year strategy starting in 2011, but the stock market crash in 2015 and subsequent slowdown fears forced Beijing to shelve its plans. Steps taken in recent months to bolster growth and revive borrowing in certain areas of the economy hint that the situation could repeat itself. However . . . One sign that things are changing is that the government is making concrete preparations to bring in such a tax, like the creation of a national land-ownership database last year, and pilot programmes in major cities such as Shanghai. “If this time around stands out from previous property tax discussions, it’s because the government has put in place the necessary infrastructure,” James Macdonald, Head of China Research at Savills, told CER. “One of the key obstacles that the government had was that they simply didn’t know who owned what – the centralised database lets them clear this hurdle.” - https://chinaeconomicreview.com/is-the-timing-right-for-a-chinese-property-tax/
China is committed to pass the law but it is too soon to pass as the process for preparation is too long. Early 2020 would be sufficient time.
Whatever Winny the Pooh wants, Winny the Pooh gets. Unless Peppa Pig gets all gangsta that is.

Some initial signals suggest it is moving in that direction (and 8 months is a long time), and although I understand it may be tricky across the entire economy, I can imagine an incrementalist approach which may draw less resistance going forward. Ultimately I'm pretty non-resilient here.
China's economy seems to be slowing down. I think it will be other way around.

1) The law would need to be passed by either the National People's Congress or the Standing Committee. ( https://blogs.loc.gov/law/2014/01/a-guide-to-chinese-legal-research-who-makes-what/ ) 2) NPC meets once a year and it is March this year which makes the October date possible.  Standing Committee meets once every other month, which means Feb, April, June, Aug, Oct are possible vote months. ( http://www.npc.gov.cn/englishnpc/news/Events/2019-01/02/content_2070226.htm , http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-12/24/c_137696105.htm ) 3) Property makes up to 13% of Chinese GDP:
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-economy-gdp/slower-property-construction-growth-drag-on-china-q3-gdp-but-services-pick-up-idUSKBN1CP0CM  Given that I believe the trade war with the US will be smoldering throughout 2019 and will negatively impact China GDP and that China cares about their GDP level, I think they will hold off on implementing the tax this year. If anyone has a link to the complete schedule for future meetings of the NPC and Standing Committee and what is on the agenda, please post as well.  I'm not really well versed enough in the problem to even know who the strongest champion is and when they will present.
It will a difficult year for Xi, he will lose political clout and some of his reforms or intentions will loose momentum.
they really don't have many dissensions in communist China so it will be pretty simple to do this.
The government needs money and wants to control the property prices. Expect tax deductions/credits for lower market properties, first property etc.

yes because china is under a lot of pressure from trade tariffs and because Europe is moving into Africa now competing for minerals diamonds etc at one stage china was dominant now uk and Europe Russia are all competing for minerals only so much minerals to go about chinas huge population would be wise to put taxes on property
The government will need to supplement funds during the recession.
The current lowed in the economy and the last two quarters of 2018 make ths very likely
If that is what Comrade XI (aka Pooh) wants, it will be so.
Interesting question.  I suspect that the Taxman cometh  just because he's gone just about everywhere else.
With China's economy slowing new taxes are becoming less likely.
Legislative process in China does not run as in democracies, Xi Jinping wants to do it, they will do it.
There is no wY they will pass up that opportunity to bring in more money.

China tax cuts effective Jan 1 2019 increases pressure on wealthy (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-02/china-s-rich-brace-for-tax-raid-on-24-trillion-wealth-pile) and other forms of tax that could accelerate property taxes. However, I expect this to be a long and complicated process, to be heavily lobbied against and not in place before 2020.

There is little time to properly implement a property tax by 10/1/19. There will be resistance by local governments and influential individuals. As a country, China has more pressing issues. "China's real estate market is already slowing. A property tax that further cools the industry -- a critical component of the economy -- would make those challenges harder to achieve. This is also a sensitive time to be tinkering with town and city finances, with Beijing having already restricted borrowing by local-government financing vehicles, a key funding conduit." [1] [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2018-03-08/don-t-bet-your-house-on-china-s-property-tax-just-yet
CP is in the process of asserting more control over the Chinese economy.

It will be a targeted tax at the rich and/or foreigners because the property market's stability is still way too important to the Chinese economy and, in a year of a projected growth slowdown, anything to hasten a slowdown will be looked upon unfavorably.  But, attacking the rich and the foreigners works in every country!

The first session of the 13th NPC Standing Committee is set to convene on March 3, 2019.  "China is moving closer to a nationwide property tax. Expected to be rubber-stamped in 2019, the levy will tame speculative market behavior and modernize the system. While legislation was long-delayed until now, actual implementation could span several more years, especially now that the economy is cooling down."[1] [1] https://thediplomat.com/2018/08/edward-cheung-on-chinas-modern-property-tax-system/

After 10 years of debate, article in China's mouthpiece suggests that terms will be finalized by the end of the year. https://www.scmp.com/business/china-business/article/2125092/china-property-tax-based-appraisal-value-legal-process-be. Anticipation of slumping market in first quarter and power of wealthy landowners/corrupt officials are only things keep me from ranking higher.

China appears to soften its stands on property tax (https://www.caixinglobal.com/2018-12-25/china-softens-tone-on-property-market-as-economic-growth-slows-101363308.html).
With the recent turmoil in the trade war and stock markets, it makes more sense for the Chinese government to act more cautiously.
at least they are recognizing Property Rights...
Seems this legislation is being fast tracked and given external pressures I think China will need to raise additional funds quickly.

From my rudimentary understanding of economics, China overall would benefit from a property tax. This is in line with Georgism, which is something I can see China moving towards. Their party makes things happen, but I can see resistance by wealthy bureaucrats in implementing this tax.

I belive the law will pass trough as it will provide more money to help people live in what now is empty buildings, which in turn will fill out empty malls and boost their economy. 
This is a big deal since 1/5 of Chinas economic activities are related to the property market.
Passing this law would increase GDP and ina  already growing economy this would make sense. There are 13 million vacant homes in China, according to Reuters.
